posts.cooked:
Our team has been trying to use LaserCAN to read when notes pass through our intake and then consequently stop our motors however the method keeps failing to respond. Our method is on lines 156-173 of the FrankenArm subsystem. Any advice on how to proceed, we’re completely lost.

Rummbly.Jr/src/main/java/frc/robot/RobotContainer.java at main · frc4087/Rummbly.Jr (github.com)

link_counts.title: LaserCAN detecting Note but won't respond Immediately

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
ChocolateFreckle:

the method keeps failing to respond

Could you clarify what this means?  Is the method hanging?  Is anything printed to the log?  Are you able to operate the sensor using the GrappleHook application?

I think we need some more information to help with your problem, but just some additional information, when using RunCommand the contents of that command run by default repeatedly with no end condition. This means when you hit A on your joystick that runIntake is being run over and over and over again and has no way to stop being called. When shootOfflauncher gets called the motors will be set to zero momentarily, but then since runIntake is being looped by RunCommand, the motors will just be set back to 0.6 on the next loop. Hopefully that’s helpful and if not then give a little more insight into what you expect to happen and what you’re observing.

posts.name: Fletch

posts.cooked: I think the the LaserCANs are reading the note but they don’t shut off the motors afterward. I’ve been experimenting with different methods over the past few days. I’ve tried some that print messages after detecting the note. I receive these messages but the motor speeds don’t change.
I’m confused by what you mean by RunCommand. If this is the issue how do I go about fixing it?

This line Rummbly.Jr/src/main/java/frc/robot/RobotContainer.java at fa8c3fe785059b90fd8f3e72de9021d1e54da6af · frc4087/Rummbly.Jr · GitHub The contents of RunCommand will be looped over indefinitely after the button press, including runIntake which is what’s probably turning your motor on over and over.

I’m not too familiar with other frameworks or styles of writing outside of the command based style, which is widely used within FRC and would be excellent for what you’re trying to do. It’d also be much easier for the CD community to help you debug. You can read more about commands here. Commands — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

To solve this with your current code I would first suggest you write down the sequence of events and triggers that you want to occur, followed by pseudocode of how those events and triggers will be included in the code. What it sounds like you’re trying to achieve is to run the motors until the sensor sees a note. One way to do that would be to use a wpilib command decorator conveniently called “until” Commands — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation . You’ll have to write a method to get the sensor state so that the until decorator has something to check, and then you can use finallyDo() to set the motors to zero. No guarantee this will work with RunCommand because I’ve never used it, but this is how you would do it as an inline command within a command based project. (There are multiple ways of writing any given command and the first method of writing a command class might make more sense or might make sense to you, it’s ultimately user preference in a lot of cases). This might be a confusing explanation so happy to elaborate further but in my experience it’s much easier to learn command based programming when you’re starting out so I would suggest at least reading more about it and discussing with anyone else on your team if it makes sense for you.
